questions.question_text: Which of the following is the most accurate NTP time source that is capable of being accessed across a network connection?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
its stratum 1 , scored a 740 on the exam i picked this

NTP servers on the internet that synchronize with stratum 1 servers (which are directly connected to atomic clocks) or stratum 2 servers (which synchronize with stratum 1 servers). These can provide accurate time for most applications.

Selected Answer: B
gpttttt

questions.question_text: A user cannot connect to the network, although others in the office are unaffected. The network technician sees that the link lights on the NIC are not on. The technician needs to check which switchport the user is connected to, but the cabling is not labeled. Which of the following is the best way for the technician to find where the computer is connected?

choices.B: Use a cable tester to trace the cable.
choices.D: Use a tone generator to trace the cable.
choices.A: Look up the computer's IP address in the switch ARP table.
choices.C: Look up the computer's MAC address in the switch CAM table.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
If the question said it was a new user then for sure D, but I could see why people would do C, however the problem with that is its not guaranteed to have it whereas if you use a tone generator the solution would be guaranteed. I think D is the correct option

Selected Answer: C
If a cable is broken (possible), a tone generator will not be able to trace the signal all the way through the cable. The CAM table should still have memory of the MAC address associated with the device from the last time it connected. I feel like dumbtia wants us to say tone generator however as this type of question always comes up.

Selected Answer: D
I'm saying D. If the link lights aren't on the it may not be in the CAM table. Best option is to tone the line.
D. tone generator

Selected Answer: C
C. Look up the computer's MAC address in the switch CAM (Content Addressable Memory) table.

The CAM table on a switch maps MAC addresses to their corresponding switch ports. By looking up the MAC address of the user's computer in the CAM table, the technician can determine which switch port it is connected to. This is often the quickest method in a network environment to locate where a specific device is connected when the cabling isn't labeled.

questions.question_text: A client recently added 100 users who are using VMs. All users have since reported slow or unresponsive desktops. Reports show minimal network congestion, zero packet loss, and acceptable packet delay. Which of the following metrics will MOST accurately show the underlying performance issues? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
I agree with the answer giving. Question states that the network looks fine, So its more than likely hardware related ie. The specs of the vm are too high for the computer the clients are working on (CPU and Memory are the most likely causing the issue)

Selected Answer: AB
A and B. Given that 100 VMs are present, it's likely exhausting resources from the system causing unresponsive system due to possible DoS (Denial of Service).

Selected Answer: AB
CPU Usage: When multiple users are utilizing virtual machines (VMs), high CPU usage can lead to slow or unresponsive desktops. If the CPU is overloaded, VMs may struggle to process user requests efficiently, resulting in performance degradation.

Memory: Insufficient memory (RAM) can also cause performance issues, especially when multiple VMs are running concurrently. If the VMs are competing for limited memory resources, it can lead to swapping or paging, slowing down overall system performance.

Selected Answer: AB
this seemed the most logical and i sort of guessed but smart guessed

Selected Answer: AB
I believe CPU usage and Memory is the defining factor if it isn't coming from Bandwidth or anything else.

Selected Answer: AB
If the problem is not associated with the networking-related layer of the system infrastructure/architecture, then you have to think about computing hardware or resources.

A. CPU usage and B. Memory are the two metrics that will most accurately show the underlying performance issues in this scenario. To accurately show the underlying performance issues in this scenario, monitoring the CPU usage and memory will be most helpful. The slow or unresponsive desktops experienced by 100 users suggest a bottleneck on the VM host. Temperature, bandwidth, latency, and jitter are unlikely to be the cause of the problem, based on the reported network metrics.
Very Broad question - Doesn't tell you if the VMs are hosted on the machines or on a Hypervisor so you have to just Ass-ume that its on the computers.

Selected Answer: AB
Network is good so computer must be bad

Selected Answer: AB
Right away I just seem it's a network issue but in the question it indicates that it is not a network issue so it's clearly a VM issue. So what slows down computers? It's going to be a memory and a CPU usage issue.

Selected Answer: AB
Technically CPU usage, Memory Usage and temperature can all affect performance but the question asks for two answers that MOST accurately show the underlying performance issues. This would only be A and B :)

Selected Answer: C
broadcast storm Traffic that is
recirculated and amplified by loops in
a switching topology, causing network
slowdowns and crashing switches.

Selected Answer: C
Broadcast storm as the switches are unmanaged.

Selected Answer: C
A broadcast storm is an abnormally high number of broadcast packets within a short period of time. They can overwhelm switches and endpoints as they struggle to keep up with processing the flood of packets. When this happens, network performance degrades.

I thought the answer was [D] Routing Loops; until I did a bit more research. My understanding now is that due to it being an unmanaged switch, there would be routing loops, but those routing loops would cause [C] Broadcase Storms, and the Broadcast Storms are the reason for the latency.

This is sort of an Event One causes Event Two which causes Event Three situation where the question is specifically asking for what caused Event Three.... 

I now understand that [C] is the correct answer.

Selected Answer: C
If you have redundant links set up, it is important to utilize STP to prevent loops within the network. If a loop occurs, the performance of the entire network can be degraded due to broadcast storms.
the trick is that they are talking about Switches not routers, the test loves to play very simple tricks so you pick the wrong answer

In a network with unmanaged Layer 2 switches and multiple connections between each pair of switches, extreme latency can be attributed to a phenomenon known as broadcast storms or network loops. 

Broadcast Storms: In an Ethernet network, broadcasts are used for various purposes, including address resolution (ARP) and DHCP requests. When a broadcast frame is sent by one device, it is typically received and processed by all devices within the broadcast domain (a LAN segment). Unmanaged switches do not have the capability to control or limit broadcast traffic.

Use Managed Switches: Consider replacing unmanaged switches with managed switches. Managed switches provide greater control and monitoring capabilities, allowing you to proactively address issues like loops and excessive broadcast traffic.
what is the solution to broadcast storms?

comments.content: making sure STP is activated in a managed switch

discussion.content: oops the trick was in the wording that I missed. It said routing loops and it tricked me because I saw the switching loop, which causes broadcast loops. The answer did not say "switching loop" but "routing loops". These are trick questions to test your eye sight

Selected Answer: C
C. A broadcast storm is most likely occurring.

questions.question_text: A technician is connecting multiple switches to create a large network for a new office. The switches are unmanaged Layer 2 switches with multiple connections between each pair. The network is experiencing an extreme amount of latency. Which of the following is MOST likely occurring?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A BYOD policy (Bring Your Own Device)
